VOL. XXXII, No. 15

BLUE JAYS DEFEAT
WILLIAM AND MARY
Hopkins Romps to Easy Win
Over Virginians
GWYNN SETS NEW RECORD
Team Entertained in Norfolk at
Football Game
Blue Jay harriers journeyed to
Williamsburg last week-end to defeat the William and Mary crosscountry team by the score of 21 to
34. As usual, the :Black and Blue
garnered both - first and second,
Gwynn and Schiebel finishing in this
order. Very little strong opposition
was furnished by the -Indians, both
of the leading Hopkins runners
having finished some time before
the first William and _Mary runner
• hove in sight. Hopkins- placed men
in first and second, fourth, sixth and
eighth positions. The result of the
race was never in doubt from the
starting gun, as the more experienced Jays settled down into a distance-devouring pace and left the
first 'Virginian far in the rear.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 22, 1927

THANKSGIVING-DAY
DANCE THURSDAY
A Thanksgiving Day dance
will be held Thursday evening
in the Maryland Casualty ballroom the night of the Maryland game. Tickets at $1.50
a couple and $1.00 stag are
now on sale.
The affair will be held under the auspices of the 1927
June Week Committee in an
effort to pay off some of debts
incurred at last year's functions. Thomas McNeal, chairman of the committee, promises an all-Hopkins affair and
asks the whole-hearted support of the student body.

Medical School To
•
Raise Tuition

DR. NIEBUHR SPEAKS
AT WEEKLY ASSEMBLY

SCHOOL CHILDREN TO
PAY HALF-PRICE
•

Detroit Minister Addresses
Students on "Can Life Be
Made Ethical?"
Several vacant rows greeted Dr.
Reinhold Niebuhr, prominent Detroit minister, when he addressed
the assembly Thursday. His subject was "Can Life Be Made Ethical ?" and he emphasized the difference between group ethics and individual ethics. "All groups are
unethical," Dr. Niebuhr said, "although the staunchest loyalty, greatest honesty and tenderest love may
exist between the members of a
given group.
Age of Disillusionment

School children of Baltimore and Washington will be
admitted to the HopkinsMaryland game at half-price.
Cards have been distributed
throughout the schools and
must be presented at the Stadium on Thursday to secure
the reduction.
It is expected this move will
add many hundreds to the attendance at the Turkey Day
classic.

A member of the student body
of the University of Cncinnati will
be fully taught to fly in one day—
at least so promise the officials of
the Embry-Riddle flying school. Arrangements have been made to have
the athletic director at Cincinnati
select twelve students whom he believes possess the characteristics desired by Embry-Riddle. These
twelve will later be voted on by the
students and the winner will be
tutored for one day only in the art

stated that his squad would start
practice November 28 and would be
prepared for the yearlings on December 3.

Discusses Armaments

Armaments had their share of
the discussion. "While the race in
armaments breeds war, absence of
armaments would not insure peace."
"What took place in this year's
Assembly disproves the charge that
the Great Powers impose their will
on the small states in the League.
Sir Austin Chamberlain's lack of
statesmanship took away from England the leadership which she, in
company with Japan and France,
has hitherto held in the field of the
League and placed it in the hands
of the smaller states."

"So well supported was the parade and St. John's game by the
freshman class, that no disciplinary
measures were necessary in the
case of the few freshmen lacking
tags on Monday and Tuesday of
last week," stated Joseph Blandi,
president of the Student Council.
Thus the matter of wearing these
tags became, as with the enforcement of other regulations, a matter
left solely to the honor of the freshman class.
Blandi is well satisfied that the
freshmen are doing their share in
the perpetuation of the voluntary
enforcement of regulations for
future classes and in the prevention of the undesired return of paddling.
The fact that regulations have
been obeyed without the use of disciplinary measures has been a distinct surprise to upper classmen.
Many of the juniors and seniors
felt, at the beginning of the year,
that paddling was necessary for
enforcement.

VOL. XXXII, No. 15

BLUE JAYS DEFEAT
WILLIAM AND MARY
Hopkins Romps to Easy Win
Over Virginians
GWYNN SETS NEW RECORD
Team Entertained in Norfolk at
Football Game
Blue Jay harriers journeyed to
Williamsburg last week-end to defeat the William and Mary crosscountry team by the score of 21 to
34. As usual, the :Black and Blue
garnered both - first and second,
Gwynn and Schiebel finishing in this
order. Very little strong opposition
was furnished by the -Indians, both
of the leading Hopkins runners
having finished some time before
the first William and _Mary runner
• hove in sight. Hopkins- placed men
in first and second, fourth, sixth and
eighth positions. The result of the
race was never in doubt from the
starting gun, as the more experienced Jays settled down into a distance-devouring pace and left the
first 'Virginian far in the rear.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 22, 1927

THANKSGIVING-DAY
DANCE THURSDAY
A Thanksgiving Day dance
will be held Thursday evening
in the Maryland Casualty ballroom the night of the Maryland game. Tickets at $1.50
a couple and $1.00 stag are
now on sale.
The affair will be held under the auspices of the 1927
June Week Committee in an
effort to pay off some of debts
incurred at last year's functions. Thomas McNeal, chairman of the committee, promises an all-Hopkins affair and
asks the whole-hearted support of the student body.

DR. NIEBUHR SPEAKS
AT WEEKLY ASSEMBLY

SCHOOL CHILDREN TO

•

Detroit Minister Addresses
Students on "Can Life Be
Made Ethical?"
Several vacant rows greeted Dr.
Reinhold Niebuhr, prominent Detroit minister, when he addressed
the assembly Thursday. His subject was "Can Life Be Made Ethical ?" and he emphasized the difference between group ethics and individual ethics. "All groups are
unethical," Dr. Niebuhr said, "although the staunchest loyalty, greatest honesty and tenderest love may
exist between the members of a
given group.

School children of Baltimore and Washington will be
admitted to the HopkinsMaryland game at half-price.
Cards have been distributed
throughout the schools and
must be presented at the Stadium on Thursday to secure
the reduction.
It is expected this move will
add many hundreds to the attendance at the Turkey Day
classic.

Lacrosse Game On December 1;
Football Game Two Days Later

Dates for the• freshman-sophomore lacrosse and football games
have at last been definitely set. It
was announced sometime ago that
the lacrosse game would be played
on December 8 and the football
game on December 10. However,
because of the cancellation of the
football game with Oglethorpe, it
was possible to push the dates further forward, so that the lacrosse
game will be played on December
1, while the football game will be
played on December 3.
Weaver Clayton, coach of the
yearling football outfit, said his
team would be ready for the sophomores on December 3. Jack Deets,
manager of the sophomore eleven,
stated that his squad would start
practice November 28 and would be
prepared for the yearlings on December 3.

a lacrosse organization meeting,
which was attended by about fifteen
men. The date of the game was announced to them and days of practice were decided upon. As the

Discusses Armaments

Armaments had their share of
the discussion. "While the race in
armaments breeds war, absence of
armaments would not insure peace."
"What took place in this year's
Assembly disproves the charge that
the Great Powers impose their will
on the small states in the League.
Sir Austin Chamberlain's lack of
statesmanship took away from England the leadership which she, in
company with Japan and France,
has hitherto held in the field of the
League and placed it in the hands
of the smaller states."

"So well supported was the parade and St. John's game by the
freshman class, that no disciplinary
measures were necessary in the
case of the few freshmen lacking
tags on Monday and Tuesday of
last week," stated Joseph Blandi,
president of the Student Council.
Thus the matter of wearing these
tags became, as with the enforcement of other regulations, a matter
left solely to the honor of the freshman class.
Blandi is well satisfied that the
freshmen are doing their share in
the perpetuation of the voluntary
enforcement of regulations for
future classes and in the prevention of the undesired return of paddling.
The fact that regulations have
been obeyed without the use of disciplinary measures has been a distinct surprise to upper classmen.
Many of the juniors and seniors
felt, at the beginning of the year,
that paddling was necessary for
enforcement.
